title: Housebuilder Persimmon sees 'robust' customer interest since Brexit vote - Chronicle Live
text:
Housebuilder Persimmon sees 'robust' customer interest since Brexit vote 14:21, 23 Aug 2016 14:21, 23 Aug 2016 By Robert Gibson Housebuilder Persimmon says demand for its homes remains encouraging, with a strong autumn sales season anticipated Shares Get business news by email Lewis Stickley/PA Wire Persimmon plc 
As Persimmon plc announces strong trading for the first half of 2016, it says customer interest remains “robust”, despite uncertainty caused by the Brexit vote. 
In the six months to June 30, the housebuilder saw profit before tax rise 29% to £352.3m, while revenues rose 12% to £1.49bn. 
The strong performance, supported by a positive trading environment, was influenced by a 6% rise in legal completions, with the number of new homes sold rising from 6,855 last year to 7,238. 
The average selling price, meanwhile, rose year-on-year from £194,378 to £205,762. 
Chief executive Jeff Fairburn said: “Persimmon’s robust trading performance in the first half of 2016 was driven by our continued focus on meeting market demand to deliver controlled sustainable growth. 
“The group’s strong cash generation has supported further disciplined land investment embedding value for the future. 
“While the result of the EU referendum has created increased economic uncertainty, customer interest since then has been robust, with visitor numbers to our sites around 20% ahead year-on-year.” 
As well as the sale of new homes, Persimmon is four years in to a decade-long strategic plan targeting disciplined land investment. 
During the half-year, it secured 7,108 plots of new land, bringing its consented land bank to 93,519 plots. It also had continued success in securing planning consent for its strategic land bank, with 2,856 plots converted. 
Trading was boosted throughout the six months by the opening of four new businesses, including that in Stockton, Teesside. 
Chairman Nicholas Wrigley said: “These new businesses have continued to make good progress in scaling up to meet local market demand whilst allowing their sister companies to optimise their delivery in adjoining territories. 
“By adopting this carefully managed approach to supporting group operations we secure high quality control over all our activities and maximise our efficiencies. We anticipate these four new businesses will deliver around 1,600 units over the next 12 months.” 
At the period end, Persimmon had net cash of £462m, up from £278m the previous year. Forward sales, meanwhile, amounted to £1.75bn.
